instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power, no MS2 light. No obvious signs of liquid damage. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.42v but PPBUS is 12.26v. Checked pins 10 and 11 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and got .521 and .524 diode mode and 3.42V present on both pins. Looked around <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> but didn't see anything crazy. I reballed the SMC becuse I thought it may have had corrosion. the board itself is drawing 13mA.

threads.message:
Bad enough.
Disconnect keyboard and check again.

threads.message: that is with board on bench

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
First check <RESISTOR>R5170</RESISTOR> value.
If OK, remove <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> and check again.
If still low, remoce <RESISTOR>R4810</RESISTOR>, to discard keyboard connector corrosion.
After all, remain only <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Removed <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> and the board is now running. I take it <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> was leaking to GND. Got a MS2 light and fan spin. put board into chassis just hear that glorious chime and got that as well as a flashing "?" folder.
